page.title: 18WAR-TIME KEMBERTON
page.content: One villager recalls the days of the Second World War when her family lived at the Mason's Arms. Then there were two classes at the village school. Both the church and Sunday School were well-attended. The rector was advisor and father figure to all. The local farms had begun to be mechanised but the horse and cart was still popular and there was still some horse ploughing. Electricity had reached the village in 1934. Doctors who served the village were at Shifnal or Madeley. There was a district nurse who travelled round the village on a bicycle. Every now and then a travelling barber visited the Mason's Arms on a Sunday morning. In those days the village shop sold most things but groceries were also delivered from Madeley and Shifnal.
